title: ASIC takes aim at financial 'sludge'
text:
"We are not tilting away from personal responsibility. We are saying it is time to rebalance the onus onto firms.

“I’d like firms to be very conscious of what ‘sludge’ they’re imposing on consumers and really get rid of unnecessary product complexity that isn’t in the best interests of consumers and their own business.”

Superannuation 'manipulated'

The pendulum shift from relying on product disclosure statements, fact sheets and fine-print warnings builds on pressure applied by the Hayne royal commission for companies to treat customers fairly.

It is a marked departure from disclosure and financial literacy being the foundations to protect consumers since the Howard government's landmark financial system inquiry by Stan Wallis in 1997.

Among the case studies over a decade contained in the ASIC-Dutch report, published on Monday night, superannuation dashboards – intended to provide a simple snapshot summary of a super product on a fund's website – were found to be "vulnerable to manipulation".

"A key implication of this research is the ease with which consumer choice could be manipulated through the ‘dashboard’ form – for example, by relabelling or reweighting asset allocation information used in the pie chart," the report notes.

Two-thirds of people were not able to locate all relevant investment fund fees and less than half could identify all super fund fees.

Advertisement

In insurance, consumers focused too much on price to the exclusion of other factors such as the terms of payouts in the event of an accident.

Only two in five Australians given a key fact sheet for insurance objectively selected the best product, with 60 per cent given suboptimal insurance.

Some 86 per cent of local consumers assessed the quality of financial advice to be good, in contrast to 39 per cent of the same advice being independently rated as poor.

Consumers were also unduly influenced by the frequency and placement of advertisements, which were treated as a proxy for the quality and safety of investment advice.

Furthermore, the complex and time-consuming sales processes fatigued consumers and rushed them into making decisions, the report said.

The 33 case studies span across Australia, the Netherlands, United States and Britain over 10 years.

Behavioural economics

Advertisement

The work was influenced by the thinking of behavioural economists and organisational psychologists, including Sunita Sah, who advised the Hayne commission that a focus on enhanced disclosure and professional ethics may be insufficient to protect customers.

Asked if ASIC was abandoning the principle of "buyer beware" or caveat emptor, Ms Chester insisted personal responsibility still had a role to play in financial consumer protection.

“Disclosure and financial literacy still matter, but if you have unnecessary complexity don’t expect it to protect consumers,” she said.

The regulatory switch reflects a recognition by ASIC's behavioral economists that the financial services market is not adequately competitive or efficient, and that relying on disclosure and financial literacy ignores the complexity of markets, cognitive biases, firms competing for consumer attention through advertising blitzes and "warnings about warnings".

ASIC, bolstered by new laws recently passed by the Federal Parliament, is already enforcing a more consumer-outcome-focused approach.

Shift to product intervention

Product intervention powers have enabled it to deal with risky and expensive short-term credit by payday lending firms such as Cigno and add-on insurance products sold by car yards.

Design and distribution obligations for financial products set expectations for firms to deliver good consumer outcomes.

Advertisement

ASIC will also lobby the government for any new laws to be written in a consumer-centric way.

The regulator is working with the government to stop firms confusing people via the conflation of general advice and personal advice, with more regulatory action due by the first half of next year.

Ms Chester said she was conscious of the regulatory burden on firms, but ASIC's new approach could reduce red tape and be good for business.

"If firms get this right, ASIC won’t need to use our product intervention powers, they’re less likely to have breach reporting and less remediation bills,” she said.

"Firms need to realise that these obligations, and them acting in the best interests of the consumers, is actually good business. They should be doing it as an insurance policy for themselves."

More than $10 billion had been paid and provisioned for in compensation and fines by finance firms in response to the Hayne commission.

In a broadside at the $2.9 superannuation industry following her report on super last year for the Productivity Commission, Ms Chester said on Monday the failure of disclosure was worse in super and she pledged to "lean in" from ASIC on default super once the Morrison government finalises its response to the PC report.

Advertisement

More than 50 of the 76 Hayne royal commission's recommendations relate to requiring better firm conduct, with only one finding on improving disclosure.

Some banks have been eradicating complex products and simplifying their offerings since the Hayne commission, with ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott and Commonwealth Bank of Australia chief Matt Comyn earlier speaking in favour of providing services and products that are good for consumers and easy to understand.

The regulatory switch follows the Coalition government's 2014 financial inquiry by former Commonwealth Bank of Australia chief executive and now AMP chairman David Murray, who similarly found disclosure was ineffective for several reasons.
description: The corporate regulator has admitted a two-decade systemic reliance on disclosure such as fine print and product warnings has failed to protect consumers of financial services.
